Troy Maxson.Action: Engages in storytelling with Bono, revealing a humorous exaggeration about a man carrying a watermelon and showing camaraderie.
Demonstrates honesty and hard work, admired by Bono, showing strength as a positive, trustworthy trait.
Shows capacity for hard work and strength, inspiring admiration from his friend Bono.
Tells an exaggerated or possibly fabricated story about the watermelon, which Bono questions as lying.
Stands up against racial job discrimination by questioning why white men drive trucks while colored men lift, files a complaint despite risks.
Supports his coworker Brownie by advising him to just tell the truth if questioned.
Firmly insists on fairness and equal opportunity for all workers regardless of race.
Takes initiative to question and challenge workplace discrimination by asking Mr. Rand why only white men drive trucks while black men do the lifting.

Responds calmly and confidently to potential job threats and accusations, showing understanding of his rights and the process.

Engages in a philosophical and practical discussion about death, showing his ability to face difficult topics with confidence and rationality.
Talks about facing Death with courage and determination, refusing to give in.
Insists his story is truthful despite Rose’s suggestion he's exaggerating.
Confronts the personification of Death, refuses to fear it, and wrestles with it for three days and nights, showing inner strength and determination.
